title: Newquay Futures
description: A virtual bike ride around Newquay looking at possible future developments.

The council working with local organisations created the VR experience through PropTech government funding. People can take a virtual tour of the town inside a VR headset, and see proposed developments. They can then give comments.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Public engagement 2022 UK Newquay Futures

title: Stonehenge Heritage & Infrastructure: VR for Engagement
description: VR was used to communicate and engage with the public on the proposed A303 Amesbury to Berwick Down Road Scheme, aimed at reducing traffic congestion around Stonehenge.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Public engagement 2023 UK National Highways

title: An augmented reality study for public participation in urban planning
description: This research explores how Augmented Reality compares to traditional methods like construction spans and 2D/3D visualizations for helping citizens understand proposed buildings.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: AR Research 2022 Switzerland

title: Virtual Reality in Planning
description: A student research project at Cal Poly that explored how VR could be used in the planning process. Working with the city of GilRoy they developed four plans for commercial spaces. The scenarios they developed could be compared on VR headsets.
They used a number of different software applications including SketchUp,  City Engine, ArcGIS, Spatial and vSpatial
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Research 2021 USA Calpoly

title: Mid Cornwall Metro: Residents View Future Transport Links in VR
description: Community engagement using VR allowed residents to experience the proposed Mid Cornwall Metro route from a unique perspective—through a virtual hot air balloon ride. This project, funded by the government's Levelling Up Fund, was created by Digital Urban, enabling residents to virtually fly over the metro route, from Newquay to Penryn.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Public engagement 2024 UK Cornwall Council

title: ExploreStation
description: An engagement led by the Design Council and delivered in partnership with a number of organisations for Network Rail, looking at transport hubs of the future. It used VR as one way to engage with people

Participants sat in railway-style seats wearing VR goggles, where they experienced a virtual train journey. The train carriage and platform were constructed around them, with seat vibrations and sounds simulating a real ride. Along the way, a voiceover and text boxes explained the Network Rail and HUB Station proposals
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Public engagement 2022 UK

title: AR to drive community engagement
description: DignityMoves, a California nonprofit focused on ending unsheltered homelessness, uses augmented reality to engage community stakeholders in the design process for interim supportive housing projects. By collaborating with Google’s Geospatial Creator and Gensler’s housing models, they provide full-scale visualizations to help communities understand project impact, streamline the design process, and ensure equitable housing solutions.
alt: an illustation of a mobile phone used to view AR
category: AR Public engagement 2023 USA DignityMoves

title: A brighter future project
description: Folkestone: A Brighter Future Project used virtual reality to engage the community in planning proposals for the town centre’s transformation. As part of the public engagement, residents could experience detailed designs for phase one, through an immersive VR tour; this included, updates to Station Approach, Cheriton Road, and Shellons Street. This technology allowed the community to explore and provide feedback on the proposed changes before they are finalised, ensuring local input shapes the future of the town centre.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Public engagement 2024 U.K. Folkestone & Hythe District Council

title: A VR Experience for Town Centre Planning
description: As part of the Farnham Infrastructure Programme's public consultation, residents were invited to explore the future of their town centre through a virtual reality experience. Held at various locations across Farnham, the immersive experience allowed participants to fly around the proposed town centre in a VR jet pack. The VR tour showcased potential changes, including widened pavements, improved pedestrian and cycling facilities, and enhancements to Castle Street, Downing Street, and The Borough

This engagement approach aimed to gather feedback from the community in a fun, interactive way while ensuring residents had a say in shaping Farnham's future. Funded by the Department of Levelling Up, Housing and Communities, the project was a collaboration between Surrey County Council, Waverley Borough Council, Farnham Town Council, and Digital Urban Place. Participants who preferred to stay grounded could explore the plans using a joystick, offering an accessible way for all to engage with the proposals.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Public engagement 2022 U.K. Surrey County Council

title: Cross River Rail Experience Centre
description: A virtual reality theatre allowed people visiting the hub at the Queensland Museum to explore the infrastructure project to help people get a better sense of the project and its scale.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Public engagement 2019 Australia Cross River Rail & Queensland Museum

title: VR for Street Re-zoning engagement
description: In Orem, Utah, VR was used to engage local residents in a neighbourhood rezoning project. Rezoning often faces local opposition or low engagement, but VR allowed people to see and experience the proposed change.
The experience helped with community engagement, making the process smoother. It received the 2019 Smart Cities Honor Award from the American Planning Association’s Technology Division.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Public engagement 2019 USA MIG

title: Multi-Sensory Virtual Reality in Participatory Planning
description: A research project exploring the multisensory immersive experiences for engagement in planning.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Research 2017 USA Rowan University Community Planning + Visualization Lab

title: VR Mississippi River Bridge
description: A  collaboration between the Iowa Department of Transportation, the ISU Virtual Reality Applications Center and the ISU Institute for Transportation that allowed people to view the bridge while it was under construction.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Public engagement 2018 USA Iowa Department of Transportation

title: Exploring the Future of Philadelphia’s Urban Landscape Through VR
description: This project used immersive virtual reality to spark dialogue about the future of Philadelphia’s urban landscape. By presenting three possible scenarios, it encouraged the community to reflect on urban green space, climate change, and sustainable design, fostering critical conversations about the challenges and opportunities in shaping a greener, healthier city.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Public engagement 2017 USA Stantec

title: Engaging Youth with AR for Oslo’s Urban Future
description: This project used Augmented Reality (AR) to involve youth in Oslo’s '100,000 New Trees' initiative. Young participants, aged 14–16, digitally placed trees and urban elements in their neighborhoods, using AR to visualize potential changes. Their designs were shared with the Municipality of Oslo to inform urban planning.
alt: an illustation of a AR device
category: AR Research 2021 Norway Oslo School of Architecture and Design

title: The effectiveness of Virtual Reality in Participatory Urban Planning
description: A study explored the effectiveness of VR in participatory urban planning within a municipal process in the Netherlands. Citizens used VR to experience proposed urban developments, providing feedback that informed planning decisions.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Research 2018 The Netherlands Municipality of The Hague & The Hague University of Applied Sciences

title: Digital Tools for Estate Regeneration
description: Birmingham City Council collaborated with partners to create digital tools for the Druids Heath regeneration project. These included virtual and augmented reality and a 3D virtual model, allowing residents to visualise potential developments and share ideas. The tools supported conversations between the community and the council, helping shape a vision for the estate’s regeneration.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Public engagement 2022 UK Birmingham City Council

title: VR Experiences Reimagining New Brighton and Seacombe
description: this project used VR to engage the community in reimagining the future of New Brighton and Seacombe. Based on ideas from local school sessions, two VR experiences were created: a virtual bus tour along New Brighton promenade and a pedalo ride along Seacombe’s waterfront.
The aim was to inspire ideas, gather feedback, and include voices often underrepresented in traditional consultations
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Public engagement 2022 UK Wirral Council

title: Testing the Ways2gether App for Urban Planning Engagement
description: The Ways2gether app was tested in two urban planning projects in Vienna: Wallensteinstrasse, a shopping street undergoing renewal, and Maria-Tusch-Strasse, a planned street in a new development area. The app used augmented reality (AR) on mobile devices to inform residents and gather feedback alongside traditional 2D and 3D visualizations. The field tests evaluated the app’s effectiveness in increasing understanding of street design plans and explored the pros and cons of AR versus traditional visualization methods.
alt: an illustation of a AR device
category: AR Research 2014 Austria  University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences, Vienna

title: CityScope Andorra: Using AR for Public Engagement and Urban Planning
description: CityScope Andorra, developed by MIT Media Lab, is an augmented reality (AR) platform that helps visualize complex urban data and supports public engagement in planning. By enabling communities to test scenarios—like adding parks, adjusting building heights, or planning mobility options—the platform fosters collaboration between citizens, urban planners, and policymakers. This innovative approach highlights how AR can enhance decision-making and create more inclusive urban development strategies.
alt: an illustation of a mobile phone used to view AR
category: AR Public engagement 2017 Andorra MIT

title: Trafford Wharfside Masterplan: A digital first platform
description: The digital platform created for The Wharfside Masterplan includes a number of ways that people can interact with the plan including 3D massing models that can be viewed in VR
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Public engagement 2024 UK Trafford Council

title: Using Virtual Reality to Involve Key Stakeholders in Hospital Design
description: Stantec used Virtual Reality (VR) in the development of a hospital tower project to gather input from key stakeholders, such as night-shift nurses. By providing a VR link, the nurses could review the design on their own schedule and provide feedback without needing in-person meetings. This approach allowed the design team to make timely adjustments based on practical insights from those who would use the space daily.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Stakeholder engagement 2024 USA Stantec

title: Engaging Communities in Climate Solutions Through AR
description: The LAR app uses Augmented Reality to engage communities and professionals in conversations about climate adjustment and urban planning. It allows users to visualise drainage and climate solutions in real-world environments, fostering understanding and collaboration. With tools for live AR visualisation and post-processed scene editing, the app bridges communication gaps and makes climate planning more accessible and interactive for everyone.
alt: an illustation of a mobile phone used to view AR
category: AR Public engagement 2020 Denmark Intertisement

title: AR Tool for Climate Change Planning and Community Engagement
description: This AR tool was developed to support dialogue between municipalities, suppliers, and local communities during climate adaptation planning. It visualises sustainable drainage solutions, such as parks and rainwater systems, directly on location. Users can place models in AR, save scenes, and later edit them offline to incorporate community feedback. By facilitating collaboration, the tool helps ensure solutions meet local needs while addressing climate challenges.
alt: an illustation of a mobile phone used to view AR
category: AR Public engagement 2018 Denmark Intertisement

title: Interactive AR Tool for Visualizing and Engaging with Architectural Designs
description: This AR tool helps architects and communities visualize building concepts by placing 3D models in real-world environments without markers. Users can walk around and explore designs, including interiors, and adjust model size, orientation, and location. It supports collaborative decision-making by allowing users to capture images and videos to share ideas. This tool makes architectural concepts more accessible, fostering creative and engaging discussions between architects, stakeholders, and communities.
alt: an illustation of a mobile phone used to view AR
category: AR Public engagement Denmark municipality of Copenhagen

title: Using AR to Engage the Public in Urban Planning for Lucerne's Bahnhofstrasse
description: The Lucerne University of Applied Sciences and Arts, in collaboration with the City of Lucerne, developed an AR visualization to engage the public in the redesign of Bahnhofstrasse and Theaterplatz. Using tablets, the tool allows users to view 3D models of proposed changes, such as new trees, bicycle stations, and seating.
alt: an illustation of a AR device
category: AR Research 2021 Switzerland The Lucerne University of Applied Sciences and Arts

title: AR-Enhanced Community Engagement for Affordable Housing in The Bronx
description: Radson Development and inCitu are using Augmented Reality to transform public engagement in urban planning for the Wakefield Yards project in The Bronx. By scanning QR codes at the development site, residents can visualise proposed affordable housing directly on their smartphones.
alt: an illustation of a mobile phone used to view AR
category: AR Public engagement 2022 USA Radson Development

title: AR-Enhanced Community Engagement for Affordable Housing in The Bronx
description: In collaboration with The Ralph Wilson Park Conservancy, inCitu used AR to engage inform and engage Buffalo residents in the planning of a new pedestrian bridge over I-190. Accessible via smartphone apps and social media, the AR experience allowed residents to visualize the bridge in their neighborhood
alt: an illustation of a mobile phone used to view AR
category: AR Public engagement 2022 USA The Ralph Wilson Park Conservancy

title: Interactive Dome Workshops for Szczecin’s Waterfront Redevelopment
description: The community were engaged in a city run competion to find an archtecture firm to redevelop Szczecin’s waterfront. The the city introduced an interactive dome experience called Hyperdome where the residents could take part in the design process. This immersive tool allowed residents to visualise future designs and participate in shaping their city’s architecture.
6000 people took part in this engagment generation 150 scene designs.
alt: an illustation of a VR device
category: VR Public engagement 2022 Poland Szczecin

title: YARD: An AR Tool for Public Space Design
description: YARD is an augmented reality tool developed by Arup to engage local communities in designing public space interventions. By allowing users to place virtual objects into real environments, YARD helps residents visualise changes, contribute their ideas, and co-create better public spaces. Originally developed as a proof of concept, YARD has since been adapted for use in vulnerable urban contexts, enabling meaningful participation in placemaking processes that are often challenging to access.
alt: an illustation of a AR device
category: AR Research 2020 Arup
